World Geography.subject: World Geography
World Geography.question: At high altitudes, pressure cooker is preferable for cooking, because the boiling point of water
options: reduces due to higher atmospheric pressure
reduces due to lower atmospheric pressure
increases due to reduced gravitational force
reduces due to increased ozone content in the atmosphere
World Geography.answer: reduces due to lower atmospheric pressure
World Geography.explanation: At high altitudes, pressure cooker is preferable for cooking because the boiling point of water reduces due to lower atmosphere pressure.

World Geography.subject: World Geography
World Geography.question: Which one of the following trains/railways passes through Germany, France, Austria, Hungary and Romania?
World Geography.explanation: The Venice Simplon-Orient-Express passed through the UK, France, Switzerland, Austria , Italy , Czech Republic, Germany, Hungary, Romania, Bulgaria and Turkey.

World Geography.subject: World Geography
World Geography.question: Tsunamis are not caused by
World Geography.explanation: Tsunami is not caused by hurricanes.

World Geography.subject: World Geography
World Geography.question: If the movement of the Earth's crust or a major climatic change makes an old stream young, it is called
World Geography.explanation: If the movement of the Earth's crust or a major climatic change makes an old stream young, it is called subsequent stream.

World Geography.subject: World Geography
World Geography.question: The jet streams are
options: wind systems with a pronounced seasonal reverse at a direction
winds blowing from the subtropical high-pressure belts towards the subpolar low-pressure belts
narrow meandering bands of swift winds which blow in the midlatitudes near the tropopause and encircle the globe
winds blowing from the subpolar low-pressure belts towards the subtropical high-pressure belts
World Geography.answer: narrow meandering bands of swift winds which blow in the midlatitudes near the tropopause and encircle the globe
World Geography.explanation: The jet streams are strong, generally westerly winds concentrated in a relatively narrowand shallow stream in the upper troposphere of the earth.

World Geography.subject: World Geography
World Geography.question: The concept of sustainable development relates to
World Geography.explanation: Intergenerational equity is a concept that says that humans 'hold the natural and cultural environment of the Earth in common both with other members of the present generation and with other generations, past and future. It means that we inherit the Earth from previous generations and have an obligation to pass it on in reasonable condition to future generations. The goal of sustainable development is Intergenerational equity.

World Geography.subject: World Geography
World Geography.question: An Earthquake epicentre is the
options: point where the seismograph is located
point within the Earth where the movement along the fault occurs
approximate centre of a group of related Earthquakes
point on the surface directly above where the rupture along the fault zone occur
World Geography.answer: point on the surface directly above where the rupture along the fault zone occur
World Geography.explanation: The epicenter is the point on the Earth's surface where an earthquake explosion originates.

World Geography.subject: World Geography
World Geography.question:
Which of the following seas are enclosed?
1. Andaman Sea
2. Arab Sea
3. Sea of Azov
4. Bering Sea
Select the correct answer using the codes given below
World Geography.explanation: Sea of Azov is a sea in south-eastern Europe. Arabian Sea is the northwestern part of the Indian Ocean.

World Geography.subject: World Geography
World Geography.question:
Match the following
List-I (Sphere of the Earth) List-II (Main Constituent of the Sphere)
A. Lithosphere 1 Living objects
B. Hydrosphere 2 Mixture of gases
C. Atmosphere 3 Water
D. Biosphere 4 Soil
World Geography.explanation: The lithosphere is the solid, outer part of the Earth. The hydrosphere is the liquid water component of the Earth.An atmosphere is the mixture of gases surrounding the Earth or other celestial body.The Biosphere is the part of the earth's surface and atmosphere inhabited by livingthings.

World Geography.subject: World Geography
World Geography.question: Bolivar is the monetary unit of
World Geography.explanation: The bolívar fuerte is the currency of Venezuela.

World Geography.subject: World Geography
World Geography.question: The time at Cairo is 2 hours ahead of Greenwich. Hence, it is located at
World Geography.explanation: Cairo is located at 30 degree east longitude.

World Geography.subject: World Geography
World Geography.question: If the earth did not have an atmosphere, temperature extremes between day and night would
World Geography.explanation: If a planet has no atmosphere, all of the sunlight which strikes it reaches the surface, and usually 90% or more of that is absorbed and 10% or less is reflected back into space. Thus the temperature will increase.

Indian Geography.subject: Indian Geography
Indian Geography.question: Which one of the following does not have a heavy water plant?
Indian Geography.explanation: Sriharikota does not have a heavy water plant. Satish Dhawan Space Centre is a rocket launch centre located in Sriharikota in Andhra Pradesh.

Indian Geography.subject: Indian Geography
Indian Geography.question: Which one of following projects of the NHPC (National Hydroelectric Power Corporation) has the largest power generation capacity (installed)?
Indian Geography.explanation: The Chamera -1 Hydroelectric project is located at the Chamba district in the state of Himachal Pradesh. The Chamera-I generates 540 MW (3x180 MW) of electricity. Salal power station is run-of-the-river scheme with an installed capacity of 690 MW (Stage-I of 3 x115 MW & Stage-II 3 X115 MW) to harnesses the Hydropower potential of river Chenab. It is located in Reasi district of Jammu & Kashmir.

Indian Geography.subject: Indian Geography
Indian Geography.question: Deltas are common in India for the East-flowing river systems, whereas they are nearly absent on the West coast, because West-flowing rivers
options: have lesser water volume and carry less run-off silt
originate largely in the Western Ghats and have short distance to cover to the sea
Indian Geography.answer: have lesser water volume and carry less run-off silt
Indian Geography.explanation: Most of the Western flowing rivers travel lesser distance than eastern flowing rivers before getting into the sea. On way to Western coast through hard rocks and over higher gradient, they couldn't collect large amount of Slit and flow with very high speed compared to East flowing rivers. Eastern rivers flow through broken hills and mountain ranges. So, they are widened and flow with lesser velocity before entering into sea. So, they deposit sediments and silt before entering into sea and can form a Delta.

Indian Geography.subject: Indian Geography
Indian Geography.question:
Which of the following statements with regard to rainfall in India is/are correct?
1. Most of the rainfall in India is due to the South-West monsoon.
2. In South India, rainfall decreases away from the Eastern Chats.
Select the correct answer using the code given below
Indian Geography.explanation: The summer or south-west monsoon comes in from the direction of Africa, and brings heavy rain to the west coast and large areas of northern India between June and August. The Western Ghats intercepts the Southwestern Monsoon winds. The Western slopes of the mountains experience heavy annual rainfall (with 80 percent of it falling during the southwest monsoon from June to September), while the Eastern slopes are drier; rainfall also decreases from South to North.

Indian Geography.subject: Indian Geography
Indian Geography.question: Which is the correct arrangement of the following rivers from North to South?
Indian Geography.explanation:
Correct sequence is Godavari- Penner- Cauveri- Periyar
The Godavari is the second longest river in India after the river Ganga. It originates from Western Ghats of central India near Nasik in Maharashtra.The Penner originates from Nandi Hills in Chikballapur District of Karnataka. This river flows from north as well as east corners across Andhra Pradesh.The Cauvery originates from Western Ghats in Karnataka and flows generally south and east through Karnataka and Tamil Nadu.The Periyar originates from Western Ghats range near the border with Tamil Nadu and flows in Kerala.

Indian Geography.subject: Indian Geography
Indian Geography.question: Consider the following features of a border district of India and identify the district using the code given below Situated at the height of 10000 feet, which is enchanted with scenic beauty, the district is surrounded by two nations in the North and South-West. River Nyamjangchu runs through it. Potato, maize and millet are the main crops of the district. Besides monasteries, tourist attractions of the district and its surrounding places include Sella Pass, PTSO, War memorial, Jaswant Garh etc. Losar is one of the prominent festivals of the district.
Indian Geography.explanation: Tawang is situated in the northwestern part of Arunachal Pradesh at an elevation of approximately 10,000 ft. The area is claimed by both the People's Republic of China and the Republic of India as a part of South Tibet.

Indian Geography.subject: Indian Geography
Indian Geography.question: Which among the following Rajdhani trains covers the longest distance?
Indian Geography.explanation: The Thiruvananthapuram Rajdhani (12431/32) is the longest running Rajdhani Express train, which covers about 3,149 km . It runs from Thiruvanathapuram Central (Kerala)to Hazrat Nizamuddin(Delhi). Thiruvananthapuram is the capital of Kerala.

Indian Geography.subject: Indian Geography
Indian Geography.question: Which one of the following places is not located on the bank of river Ganga?
Indian Geography.explanation: Uttarkashi is not located on the bank of river Ganga.

Indian Geography.subject: Indian Geography
Indian Geography.question: On the map of India, the shaded districts are those in which a particular tribal group constitutes more than 50% of the tribal population. What is that particular tribal group?
Indian Geography.explanation: Santhals are the largest tribal group in India who lives mainly in Assam, odisha, Bihar, West Bengal and Jharkhand.

Indian Geography.subject: Indian Geography
Indian Geography.question: Which one of the following is not associated with monsoon climate in India?
options: South-equatorial warm currents of Indian Ocean
Indian Geography.answer: South-equatorial warm currents of Indian Ocean
Indian Geography.explanation: The South Equatorial Current is a significant Pacific, Atlantic, and Indian Ocean current that flows east-to-west between the equator and about 20 degrees south.

Indian Geography.subject: Indian Geography
Indian Geography.question: Which one of die following statements is not correct regarding the Himalayas?
options: Hmalayas have nappe and recumbent folds
Himalayas rose up from the Tethys Sea
Himalayas contain three mountain ranges-Siwaliks, Great Himalayas and kunlun Ranges
The orogeny took place in the Tertiary Era
Indian Geography.answer: Himalayas contain three mountain ranges-Siwaliks, Great Himalayas and kunlun Ranges
Indian Geography.explanation: Himalayas contain three mountain ranges the Himadri (greater Himalaya), Himachal (lesser Himalaya) and the Shiwaliks (outer Himalaya).

Indian Geography.subject: Indian Geography
Indian Geography.question: Which one of the following statements on biosphere reserves is not correct?
options: In 1971, UNESCO launched a worldwide programme on man and biosphere
Biosphere reserves promote research on ecological conservation
Nanda Devi Biosphere Reserve is located in Madhya pradesh
Biosphere reserves are multipurpose protected areas to preserve the genetic diversity in ecosystems
Indian Geography.answer: Nanda Devi Biosphere Reserve is located in Madhya pradesh
Indian Geography.explanation: Nanda Devi Biosphere Reserve is located in Uttarakhand. It was inscribed a World Heritage Site by UNESCO in 1988.
